answers.author: David Collinsworth
answers.text:
James - the City of Westerville, Ohio utilizes a five-year financial planning document that serves as our budget document.  While we only appropriate for one fiscal year at a time, we have a projection of revenues and expenses that run out four more years.  If you are interested in more detailed information, let me know and I'll post some doc's for you.
Dave Collinsworth
City Manager

answers.author: Michael Repas
answers.text:
Hi James:
I found a spreadsheet for a 1-year projection and therefore will give you a good start on modifying them for use in your local government, as desired.  You can make it into as many years as you need by adding sheets to your spreadsheet, or by simply making it bigger within the same sheet.  It is uploaded to the Knowledge Network Library, and available here:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301291/Sample_Local_Government_Finanical_Projection_Spreadsheet 
Hopefully this is a good start for you!

answers.author: Brian Wolverton
answers.text:
I've attached an example of what I use to do projections.  In terms of methodology, I treat each line item individually.  For payroll items, I have a worksheet that projects person by person, pay period by pay period.  If that's too onerous, you can just calculate an aggregate number and do your best to factor in longevity, stipends, etc... there are very few items I do linear projections for, because there are so few expenses that are linear.  I just meet with departments eithe rmonthly or quarterly and go through each line item with them to ask them when they think big expenses will take place, and how things like utilities and repairs are shaking out, and build projections off of what I get from those meetings.  It's far more accurate than just trying to apply a formula.  This format could be stretched out for multiple years easily enough, though multi-year expense forecasting is somewhat futile when the council makes big cuts every year.
I also attached a multi-year projection worksheet we use for our Water & Sewer enterprise fund.  It ties in a lot of variables, including projected consumption, our rate increase plan, desired reserve levels, future projects, etc.  This one is very complex but more algorhythmic and perhaps more of what you're looking for.
Hope this helps!
